articles.headline: TikTok Accepts Deal Revisions as Trump Prepares to Review Proposal
articles.snippet: The video app is also looking for a new chief executive and has talked to candidates including a founder of Instagram.
articles.abstract: The video app is also looking for a new chief executive and has talked to candidates including a founder of Instagram.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Chinese company that owns TikTok has accepted the Trump administration’s changes to a deal designed to mitigate the White House’s concerns that the popular app poses a national security threat, two people with knowledge of the talks said.
articles.byline: By David McCabe, Erin Griffith, Ana Swanson and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Unemployment Claims Dip, but Layoffs Remain a Worry
articles.snippet: “I’m concerned about a plateau,” one economist said, pointing to a slower phase of the recovery after a hiring bounce in the spring.
articles.abstract: “I’m concerned about a plateau,” one economist said, pointing to a slower phase of the recovery after a hiring bounce in the spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits fell last week, but employers continue to lay off workers at an extraordinarily high pace that exceeds the worst levels of past recessions.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Gillian Friedman

articles.headline: For Trump, It’s Not the United States, It’s Red and Blue States
articles.snippet: A statement by President Trump this week was an insight into how he views the country as composed of parts that either are for him or against him.
articles.abstract: A statement by President Trump this week was an insight into how he views the country as composed of parts that either are for him or against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump argued this week that the death toll from the coronavirus was actually not so bad. All you had to do was not count states that voted for Democrats.

articles.headline: Wildfires Are Latest Risk in the Rewarding Quiet of Gold Country
articles.snippet: California’s numerous fires are challenging the survival of some of the state’s oldest and most storied small communities.
articles.abstract: California’s numerous fires are challenging the survival of some of the state’s oldest and most storied small communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSH CREEK, Calif. — Of the hundreds of homes rendered to ash by a ferocious wildfire this month in the mountains on the northeastern edge of California, one had particular historical significance. Mountain House, a former stagecoach hotel with its saloon-style second-story balcony and steep roof, was a relic of the gold rush, a stop on the way to the mining towns that dot the thickly forested slopes and canyons of the Sierra Nevada.

articles.headline: Housekeepers Face a Disaster Generations in the Making
articles.snippet: Ghosted by their employers, members of the profession are facing “a full-blown humanitarian crisis — a Depression-level situation.”
articles.abstract: Ghosted by their employers, members of the profession are facing “a full-blown humanitarian crisis — a Depression-level situation.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The scariest day of Maria Del Carmen’s life started with a phone call that initially cheered her up.

articles.headline: A Danish Children’s TV Show Has This Message: ‘Normal Bodies Look Like This’
articles.snippet: The program aims to counter social media that bombards young people with images of perfect bodies.
articles.abstract: The program aims to counter social media that bombards young people with images of perfect bodies.
articles.lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — “OK, children, does anyone have a question?” the TV show’s host, Jannik Schow, asked. Only a few in the audience of 11- to 13-year-olds raised their hands. “Remember, you can’t do anything wrong,” he said. “There are no bad questions.”
articles.byline: By Thomas Erdbrink and Martin Selsoe Sorensen

articles.headline: Trump Administration to Ban TikTok and WeChat From U.S. App Stores
articles.snippet: It issued new rules that will cripple the operation of two popular Chinese-owned apps in the United States.
articles.abstract: It issued new rules that will cripple the operation of two popular Chinese-owned apps in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration said Friday it would bar the Chinese-owned mobile apps WeChat and TikTok from U.S. app stores as of midnight Sunday, a significant escalation in America’s tech fight with China that takes aim at two popular services used by more than 100 million people in the United States.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, David McCabe and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: What Is Happening With TikTok and WeChat as Trump Tries to Ban Them?
articles.snippet: The Commerce Department announced that it was prohibiting downloads of WeChat and TikTok in U.S. app stores. Here’s what you need to know.
articles.abstract: The Commerce Department announced that it was prohibiting downloads of WeChat and TikTok in U.S. app stores. Here’s what you need to know.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is pushing forward with its plan to ban the Chinese social media apps TikTok and WeChat from American app stores.
